abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Rice Development
            Project for Guinea was satisfactory. The project achieved
            its main objectives, its impact has been significant on
            agricultural development, and both the Bank and Borrower
            performed satisfactorily. Several lessons can be learned
            from this project. First, the project demonstrated to the
            Government that a smallholder orientation was a more
            effective and less costly approach to development than
            collectives or state farmers. Second, the project's
            success can be attributed to the particular attention paid
            to avoiding parallel organizational structures. Third, the
            project was able to successfully test simple technical
            packages that promoted low cost yield improvements by using
            simple technology such as improved seed, fertilizer, simple
            water control, and crop husbandry improvements. Finally, IDA
            supervision in the areas of accounting, financial
            management, and credit recovery was weak since supervision
            efforts concentrated on technical and administrative matters.
